title: How to Make Produce Bags

steps.headline: Choose a fabric material for the bag's pouch.
steps.description: There is a world of fabrics to choose from, but the goal is to use a material that is durable, lightweight, and allows air flow. The bag will be weighed along with your produce, so avoid heavy fabrics. Some common materials for produce bags include cotton, muslin, and synthetic and natural mesh. Cotton fabric: Stretchy, soft, and breathable. Good for holding a large volume of produce, but may not be as strong as some other options. Muslin: Can come in various thicknesses, but use a thin version for these bags. Not very stretchy, but durable and can be patterned. Nylon mesh: A very strong material, with large holes in the material making it look woven. Natural mesh: Similar to the nylon mesh, this is a durable and strong material, but made with natural fibers instead of synthetic ones.

steps.headline: Separate the fabric into 20 in (51 cm) by 16 in (41 cm) rectangles.
steps.description: You should be able to get eight equally-sized portions if you have a 2 yd (1.8 m) piece of fabric to work with. Use your fabric marker to mark where you will cut the fabric away. If you have an original piece of fabric slightly smaller or larger than 2 yd (1.8 m), try to get as close to these measurements as you can. You may need to change the number of pieces you cut out to fit the size of  your fabric.

steps.headline: Cut out squares of fabric to use as your pouch.
steps.description: Try to follow your markings as closely as you can so in later steps they will align correctly. Don't worry if you fray the edges or you go slightly outside the lines - you will cut away about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) of fabric from each side later on. If you end up with slightly more or less than eight rectangles, make sure you at least have an even number available to you. You need two pieces of fabric per bag.

steps.headline: Cut cotton rope into four 24 in (61 cm) long strands.
steps.description: These ropes will be used to create a drawstring at the top of the bag. Make sure that each length of rope is about a fifth longer than the length of your now cut-out fabric rectangles, to provide ends to tie the bag closed. To prevent the rope from fraying and becoming unusable, you can use a fray preventing product at each end. If you don't have access to cotton rope, you can use a ribbon instead. Just be sure the ribbon is strong enough to handle being stretched and tightened.

steps.headline: Lay two pieces of fabric on top of each other, and align the edges.
steps.description: Make sure the edges line up as close as they can, and make a marking about 1 in (2.5 cm) from the top edge with your fabric marker. This will be the point to which  you fold over the top to create a hollow lip where the drawstring will go through. Don't worry about cutting the frayed or unsmooth edges of the fabric yet. In a later step, you will cut off this extra fabric from each edge after you sew them together.

steps.headline: Pin along the sides and bottom, and stop at the top edge.
steps.description: Don't pin together the top edge as you will need to leave an unsewn edge to serve as a hole. Place pins close enough to keep the two pieces of fabric securely fastened together. Make sure you don't accidentally nudge the layers out of alignment during this step. It's important to keep them closely lined up so as to prevent problems when you sew it together.

steps.headline: Fold the top 1 in (2.5 cm) in half to the line.
steps.description: The top 1 in (2.5 cm) should not go over the line you marked earlier, instead it should be folded in half so the hole the rope will be inserted into is about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) wide, creating a hollow lip at the top of the bag.

steps.headline: Sew the sides and bottom edge, with a 0.5 in (1.3 cm) allowance.
steps.description: Sew tightly giving yourself extra room on each side. Do not remove the pins until you have finished, as they will help to keep the fabric together until the seam holds. Cut the allowance away from each edge seam once you have finished sewing, and then remove the pins. You can use a sewing machine during this step if you wish, but be sure to keep the top edge away from you to make sure the seams are as strong as they can be.

steps.headline: Stitch the lip shut and insert a length of rope.
steps.description: Sew as closely to the end of the fabric as you can to leave more than enough space for the rope to fit through, including the seam. There should be two points of entry on each side of the lip. Thread the rope through both sides so that you end up with both ends coming out of the same side. You should not have to cut off much, if any, fabric after this step. There should be enough rope to allow for a small length to poke out from each end. If you don't have enough extra to be able to tighten the drawstring around the lip, cut another longer piece of rope to use.

steps.headline: Test its strength and volume by putting items in the bag.
steps.description: Place heavy foods and items into the bag to test its strength. Pack it full of produce you have at home to test how many items you can fit in the bag at one time. If the bag feels weak and cannot carry heavy items, you can stitch the bag's edges and top fold again to make it stronger. Either remove the stitches you already sewed, or sew another line adjacent to the current seams. If the produce bag is not as large as you would like, you can use it as a bag to carry the others you made to reduce the space they take up on your counter or in your cabinet. Next time you make your own bags, increase the size of the fabric rectangles you cut to adjust for extra room.

tyn: 4 yd (3.7 m) Cotton string or rope
text: Choosing and Cutting Fabric Choose a fabric material for the bag's pouch. There is a world of fabrics to choose from, but the goal is to use a material that is durable, lightweight, and allows air flow. The bag will be weighed along with your produce, so avoid heavy fabrics. Some common materials for produce bags include cotton, muslin, and synthetic and natural mesh. Cotton fabric: Stretchy, soft, and breathable. Good for holding a large volume of produce, but may not be as strong as some other options. Muslin: Can come in various thicknesses, but use a thin version for these bags. Not very stretchy, but durable and can be patterned. Nylon mesh: A very strong material, with large holes in the material making it look woven. Natural mesh: Similar to the nylon mesh, this is a durable and strong material, but made with natural fibers instead of synthetic ones. Separate the fabric into 20 in (51 cm) by 16 in (41 cm) rectangles. You should be able to get eight equally-sized portions if you have a 2 yd (1.8 m) piece of fabric to work with. Use your fabric marker to mark where you will cut the fabric away. If you have an original piece of fabric slightly smaller or larger than 2 yd (1.8 m), try to get as close to these measurements as you can. You may need to change the number of pieces you cut out to fit the size of  your fabric. Cut out squares of fabric to use as your pouch. Try to follow your markings as closely as you can so in later steps they will align correctly. Don't worry if you fray the edges or you go slightly outside the lines - you will cut away about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) of fabric from each side later on. If you end up with slightly more or less than eight rectangles, make sure you at least have an even number available to you. You need two pieces of fabric per bag. Cutting, Layering, and Pinning Cut cotton rope into four 24 in (61 cm) long strands. These ropes will be used to create a drawstring at the top of the bag. Make sure that each length of rope is about a fifth longer than the length of your now cut-out fabric rectangles, to provide ends to tie the bag closed. To prevent the rope from fraying and becoming unusable, you can use a fray preventing product at each end. If you don't have access to cotton rope, you can use a ribbon instead. Just be sure the ribbon is strong enough to handle being stretched and tightened. Lay two pieces of fabric on top of each other, and align the edges. Make sure the edges line up as close as they can, and make a marking about 1 in (2.5 cm) from the top edge with your fabric marker. This will be the point to which  you fold over the top to create a hollow lip where the drawstring will go through. Don't worry about cutting the frayed or unsmooth edges of the fabric yet. In a later step, you will cut off this extra fabric from each edge after you sew them together. Pin along the sides and bottom, and stop at the top edge. Don't pin together the top edge as you will need to leave an unsewn edge to serve as a hole. Place pins close enough to keep the two pieces of fabric securely fastened together. Make sure you don't accidentally nudge the layers out of alignment during this step. It's important to keep them closely lined up so as to prevent problems when you sew it together. Sewing the Bag Together Fold the top 1 in (2.5 cm) in half to the line. The top 1 in (2.5 cm) should not go over the line you marked earlier, instead it should be folded in half so the hole the rope will be inserted into is about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) wide, creating a hollow lip at the top of the bag. Sew the sides and bottom edge, with a 0.5 in (1.3 cm) allowance. Sew tightly giving yourself extra room on each side. Do not remove the pins until you have finished, as they will help to keep the fabric together until the seam holds. Cut the allowance away from each edge seam once you have finished sewing, and then remove the pins. You can use a sewing machine during this step if you wish, but be sure to keep the top edge away from you to make sure the seams are as strong as they can be. Stitch the lip shut and insert a length of rope. Sew as closely to the end of the fabric as you can to leave more than enough space for the rope to fit through, including the seam. There should be two points of entry on each side of the lip. Thread the rope through both sides so that you end up with both ends coming out of the same side. You should not have to cut off much, if any, fabric after this step. There should be enough rope to allow for a small length to poke out from each end. If you don't have enough extra to be able to tighten the drawstring around the lip, cut another longer piece of rope to use. Test its strength and volume by putting items in the bag. Place heavy foods and items into the bag to test its strength. Pack it full of produce you have at home to test how many items you can fit in the bag at one time. If the bag feels weak and cannot carry heavy items, you can stitch the bag's edges and top fold again to make it stronger. Either remove the stitches you already sewed, or sew another line adjacent to the current seams. If the produce bag is not as large as you would like, you can use it as a bag to carry the others you made to reduce the space they take up on your counter or in your cabinet. Next time you make your own bags, increase the size of the fabric rectangles you cut to adjust for extra room.
sentences: Choosing and Cutting Fabric Choose a fabric material for the bag's pouch.
There is a world of fabrics to choose from, but the goal is to use a material that is durable, lightweight, and allows air flow.
The bag will be weighed along with your produce, so avoid heavy fabrics.
Some common materials for produce bags include cotton, muslin, and synthetic and natural mesh.
Cotton fabric: Stretchy, soft, and breathable.
Good for holding a large volume of produce, but may not be as strong as some other options.
Muslin: Can come in various thicknesses, but use a thin version for these bags.
Not very stretchy, but durable and can be patterned.
Nylon mesh: A very strong material, with large holes in the material making it look woven.
Natural mesh: Similar to the nylon mesh, this is a durable and strong material, but made with natural fibers instead of synthetic ones.
Separate the fabric into 20 in (51 cm) by 16 in (41 cm) rectangles.
You should be able to get eight equally-sized portions if you have a 2 yd (1.8 m) piece of fabric to work with.
Use your fabric marker to mark where you will cut the fabric away.
If you have an original piece of fabric slightly smaller or larger than 2 yd (1.8 m), try to get as close to these measurements as you can.
You may need to change the number of pieces you cut out to fit the size of  your fabric.
Cut out squares of fabric to use as your pouch.
Try to follow your markings as closely as you can so in later steps they will align correctly.
Don't worry if you fray the edges or you go slightly outside the lines - you will cut away about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) of fabric from each side later on.
If you end up with slightly more or less than eight rectangles, make sure you at least have an even number available to you.
You need two pieces of fabric per bag.
Cutting, Layering, and Pinning Cut cotton rope into four 24 in (61 cm) long strands.
These ropes will be used to create a drawstring at the top of the bag.
Make sure that each length of rope is about a fifth longer than the length of your now cut-out fabric rectangles, to provide ends to tie the bag closed.
To prevent the rope from fraying and becoming unusable, you can use a fray preventing product at each end.
If you don't have access to cotton rope, you can use a ribbon instead.
Just be sure the ribbon is strong enough to handle being stretched and tightened.
Lay two pieces of fabric on top of each other, and align the edges.
Make sure the edges line up as close as they can, and make a marking about 1 in (2.5 cm) from the top edge with your fabric marker.
This will be the point to which  you fold over the top to create a hollow lip where the drawstring will go through.
Don't worry about cutting the frayed or unsmooth edges of the fabric yet.
In a later step, you will cut off this extra fabric from each edge after you sew them together.
Pin along the sides and bottom, and stop at the top edge.
Don't pin together the top edge as you will need to leave an unsewn edge to serve as a hole.
Place pins close enough to keep the two pieces of fabric securely fastened together.
Make sure you don't accidentally nudge the layers out of alignment during this step.
It's important to keep them closely lined up so as to prevent problems when you sew it together.
Sewing the Bag Together Fold the top 1 in (2.5 cm) in half to the line.

The top 1 in (2.5 cm) should not go over the line you marked earlier, instead it should be folded in half so the hole the rope will be inserted into is about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) wide, creating a hollow lip at the top of the bag.
Sew the sides and bottom edge, with a 0.5 in (1.3 cm) allowance.
Sew tightly giving yourself extra room on each side.
Do not remove the pins until you have finished, as they will help to keep the fabric together until the seam holds.
Cut the allowance away from each edge seam once you have finished sewing, and then remove the pins.
You can use a sewing machine during this step if you wish, but be sure to keep the top edge away from you to make sure the seams are as strong as they can be.
Stitch the lip shut and insert a length of rope.
Sew as closely to the end of the fabric as you can to leave more than enough space for the rope to fit through, including the seam.
There should be two points of entry on each side of the lip.
Thread the rope through both sides so that you end up with both ends coming out of the same side.
You should not have to cut off much, if any, fabric after this step.
There should be enough rope to allow for a small length to poke out from each end.
If you don't have enough extra to be able to tighten the drawstring around the lip, cut another longer piece of rope to use.
Test its strength and volume by putting items in the bag.
Place heavy foods and items into the bag to test its strength.
Pack it full of produce you have at home to test how many items you can fit in the bag at one time.
If the bag feels weak and cannot carry heavy items, you can stitch the bag's edges and top fold again to make it stronger.
Either remove the stitches you already sewed, or sew another line adjacent to the current seams.
If the produce bag is not as large as you would like, you can use it as a bag to carry the others you made to reduce the space they take up on your counter or in your cabinet.
Next time you make your own bags, increase the size of the fabric rectangles you cut to adjust for extra room.
